case_name: Ahmedabad Miscellaneous Industrial Workers Union v. Ahmedabad Electricity Company Limited

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 479 of 1960

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 479 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 13, 1959, of the Industrial Court Bombay in Ref. I.C. No. 159 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 13, 1959, of the Industrial Court Bombay in Ref.  f.C.  No. 159 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on July 28, 1961 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. July 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave in an industrial matter.

facts.text: Appellant is the Ahmedabad Miscellaneous Industrial Workers Union

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Ahmedabad Miscellaneous Industrial Workers Union, and the dispute which went for adjudication before the Industrial Court Bombay

facts.text: Respondent is the Ahmedabad Electricity Company Limited

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed that three months I wages should be awarded as bonus by the respondent, which is the Ahmedabad Electricity Company Limited.

facts.text: Dispute with respect to bonus for the year ending September 1956

anchor.surface_text: and the dispute which went for adjudication before the Industrial Court Bombay was with respect to bonus for the year ending Septem- ber 1956.

facts.text: Appellant claimed three months wages as bonus

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed that three months I wages should be awarded as bonus by the respondent,

facts.text: Respondent contended no available surplus per Full Bench Formula approved in Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. Its Workmen

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the respondent was that if a calculation was made in accordance with the Full Bench Formula evolved by the Labour Appellate Tribunal and approved by this Court in the Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. Its Workmen  1 , there would be numberavailable surplus

facts.text: Industrial Court accepted respondent's contention and rejected appellant's claim

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court accepted the companytention of the respondent and rejected the appel- lants claim.

facts.text: Main dispute centred on three points: depreciation per Income-tax Act vs Seventh Schedule to Electricity Supply Act, contingencies reserve deduction, income-tax deduction

anchor.surface_text: The main dispute in the Industrial Court centred on three points namely- whether depreciation should be cal- culated according to the provisions of the Income-tax Act and the rules framed thereunder or in accordance with the provisions companytained in the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity  Supply  Act, No. LIV of 1918 whether any deduction should be allowed as a prior charge towards companytingencies reserve created under the Electricity  Supply  Act and whether any deduction should be allowed on account of income-tax.

facts.text: Industrial Court held against appellant on all three points

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court held against the appellant on all the three points and found that there was numberavailable surplus from which any bonus companyld be awarded.

facts.text: Industrial Court found no available surplus for bonus

anchor.surface_text: and found that there was numberavailable surplus from which any bonus companyld be awarded. Hence this appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Not in dispute that if depreciation calculated per Income-tax Act rules, no available surplus for bonus

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute between the parties that if depreciation is calculated in accordance with the rules framed under the Income-tax Act, there will be numberavailable surplus, from which bonus companyld be awarded.

facts.text: U. P. Electric Supply Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen decided in 1955 by Appellate Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: What depreciation should be allowed in the case of electricity companypanies came lip for companysideration before the Appellate Tribunal in 1955 in the case of U. P. Electric Supply Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen  1 ,

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal in U.P. Electric case preferred income-tax depreciation over Seventh Schedule

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal pointed out that in the long run the result of the application of the two methods would be the same but it preferred to give as prior charge income-tax depreciation as it was in keeping with the Full Bench formula and was number likely to raise fresh problems.

facts.text: Various Industrial Tribunals have allowed depreciation according to income-tax rates for electricity companies

anchor.surface_text: It appears that since then, as pointed out by the Industrial Court, various Industrial Tribunals have been allowing depreciation according to the income-tax rates and number according to the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity  Supply  Act in the case of electricity companypanies also.

facts.text: Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen approved U.P. Electric case on depreciation

anchor.surface_text: The P. Electric Supply Companys case  1  came up for companysideration before this Court in The Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen  2  and was approved.

facts.text: This Court approved income-tax rates depreciation for Full Bench formula

anchor.surface_text: This Court then approved the decision of the Appellate, Tribunal disallowing initial and additional depreciation in calculating depreciation for purposes of the Full Bench formula but accepted that depreciation according to income-tax rates should be deducted.

facts.text: Tinnevelly-Tutcorin Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen dealt with electricity company directly

anchor.surface_text: Further in The Tinnevelly-Tutcorin Electric Supply Co. Ltd. Its Workmen  1 , this Court dealt with the case of an electricity companypany directly.

facts.text: Full Bench Formula evolved by Labour Appellate Tribunal and approved by Supreme Court in Associated Cement Companies case 1959 S.C.R. 925

anchor.surface_text: in accordance with the Full Bench Formula evolved by the Labour Appellate Tribunal and approved by this Court in the Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. Its Workmen  1 ,

facts.text: Electricity Supply Act No. LIV of 1918

anchor.surface_text: in accordance with the provisions companytained in the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity  Supply  Act, No. LIV of 1918

facts.text: Court holds depreciation per Income-tax rules for Full Bench formula even for electricity companies

anchor.surface_text: But, assuming that the question is still open because it was never directly raised in this Court and specifically decided, we are of opinion that the income-tax rules should be applied in working out depreciation under the Full Bench formula in preference to the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity  Supply  Act.

facts.text: U.P. Electric Supply case settled law in 1955 and followed throughout country for six years

anchor.surface_text: That case settled the law in 1955 and has since been followed throughout the companyntry. We feel that we should number disturb that decision, unless there are good reasons for doing so and numbere I has been shown.
Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 13, 1959, of the Industrial Court Bombay in Ref.  f.C.  No. 159 of 1957.

arguments.claim: Not open to appellant to argue for Seventh Schedule depreciation over income-tax rates given precedents

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances it seems to us that it is number open to the appellant to raise the question that the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act should be applied for purposes of calculating depreciation in preference to the income-tax rates

arguments.claim: Income-tax rules should be applied for depreciation under Full Bench formula in preference to Seventh Schedule

anchor.surface_text: But, assuming that the question is still open because it was never directly raised in this Court and specifically decided, we are of opinion that the income-tax rules should be applied in working out depreciation under the Full Bench formula in preference to the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity  Supply  Act.

arguments.claim: Electricity Supply Act provisions (s.57, Sch VI & VII) for consumer charges, not industrial adjudication

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out in Tinnvelly Tuticorin ElectriG Supply Co.s case  1  that the provisions in the Electricity  Supply  Act companytained in s. 57 and the Sixth and Seventh Schedules to the Act were for a special purpose, namely, to work out the charges to be recovered from companysumers

arguments.claim: Same depreciation principle under Full Bench formula for electricity companies as other industries for uniformity

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us therefore that in working, out available surplus according to the Full Bench formula, the same principle with respect to depreciation should be applied in the case of electricity companypanies as in the case of all other industrial companycerns.

arguments.claim: Full Bench formula evolved using income-tax depreciation rates

anchor.surface_text: This will work for uniformity in all industrial companycerns and as pointed out in the Associated Cement Companies case the formula had on the whole worked fairly satisfactorily in a large number of industries all over the companyntry

arguments.claim: Injecting Seventh Schedule into formula destroys uniformity; electricity companies would differ from others, undesirable for public utilities

anchor.surface_text: This will work for uniformity in all industrial companycerns and as pointed out in the Associated Cement Companies case the formula had on the whole worked fairly satisfactorily in a large number of industries all over the companyntry, and the claim for bonus should be decided by tribunals on the basis of this formula without attempting to revise it.

arguments.claim: Income-tax depreciation rates build quicker depreciation fund, beneficial for public utility electricity companies facing unforeseen replacements

anchor.surface_text: Another reason why we think that income-tax rates of depreciation should be applied for the purposes of the Full Bench formula in the case of electricity companypanies also is that income-tax rates provide for a quicker building up of the depreciation fund.

arguments.claim: U.P. Electric Supply case settled law in 1955, followed nationwide for six years; not to disturb especially with bonus formula under commission review

anchor.surface_text: That case settled the law in 1955 and has since been followed throughout the companyntry. We feel that we should number disturb that decision, unless there are good reasons for doing so and numbere I has been shown.

holdings.text: it is not open to the appellant to raise the question that the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act should be applied for purposes of calculating depreciation in preference to the income-tax rates in working out the Full Bench formula

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances it seems to us that it is number open to the appellant to raise the question that the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity  Supply  Act should be applied for purposes of calculating depreciation in preference to the income-tax rates in working out the Full Bench formula.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents in U.P. Electric Supply, Shree Meenakshi Mills, and Tinnevelly-Tutcorin Electric Supply cases approved income-tax depreciation for electricity companies under Full Bench formula

holdings.text: the income-tax rules should be applied in working out depreciation under the Full Bench formula in preference to the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act

anchor.surface_text: But, assuming that the question is still open because it was never directly raised in this Court and specifically decided, we are of opinion that the income-tax rules should be applied in working out depreciation under the Full Bench formula in preference to the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity  Supply  Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Electricity Supply Act provisions meant for consumer charges not industrial adjudication; requires uniformity across industries; Full Bench formula evolved using income-tax rates; quicker depreciation fund beneficial for public utilities

holdings.text: the provisions in the Electricity Supply Act contained in s. 57 and the Sixth and Seventh Schedules to the Act were for a special purpose, namely, to work out the charges to be recovered from consumers [...] the principles of industrial adjudication were wholly different

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out in Tinnvelly Tuticorin ElectriG Supply Co.s case  1  that the provisions in the Electricity  Supply  Act companytained in s. 57 and the Sixth and Seventh Schedules to the Act were for a special purpose, namely, to work out the charges to be recovered from companysumers

holdings.reasoning_summary: Citing Tinnevelly-Tutcorin case, provisions of Electricity Supply Act operate in different field from industrial adjudication principles

holdings.text: in working out available surplus according to the Full Bench formula, the same principle with respect to depreciation should be applied in the case of electricity companies as in the case of all other industrial concerns

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us therefore that in working, out available surplus according to the Full Bench formula, the same principle with respect to depreciation should be applied in the case of electricity companypanies as in the case of all other industrial companycerns.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniformity in application of Full Bench formula across all industries prevents disparate bonus outcomes

holdings.text: we should not disturb [the U. P. Electric Supply Company's case decision], unless there are good reasons for doing so and none has been shown

anchor.surface_text: That case settled the law in 1955 and has since been followed throughout the companyntry. We feel that we should number disturb that decision, unless there are good reasons for doing so and numbere I has been shown.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decision settled law in 1955, followed nationwide for six years; bonus formula under review by commission

holdings.text: the claim for bonus should be decided by tribunals on the basis of this formula without attempting to revise it

anchor.surface_text: This will work for uniformity in all industrial companycerns and as pointed out in the Associated Cement Companies case the formula had on the whole worked fairly satisfactorily in a large number of industries all over the companyntry, and the claim for bonus should be decided by tribunals on the basis of this formula without attempting to revise it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Formula has worked satisfactorily; injecting special provisions destroys uniformity especially undesirable for public utility concerns

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances it seems to us that it is number open to the appellant to raise the question that the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act should be applied for purposes of calculating depreciation in preference to the income-tax rates in working out the Full Bench formula. But, assuming that the question is still open because it was never directly raised in this Court and specifically decided, we are of opinion that the income-tax rules should be applied in working out depreciation under the Full Bench formula in preference to the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances it seems to us that it is number open to the appellant to raise the question that the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity  Supply  Act should be applied for purposes of calculating depreciation in preference to the income-tax rates in working out the Full Bench formula.

In the circumstances it seems to us that it is number open to the appellant to raise the question that the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act should be applied for purposes of calculating depreciation in preference to the income-tax rates in working out the Full Bench formula. But, assuming that the question is still open because it was never directly raised in this Court and specifically decided, we are of opinion that the income-tax rules should be applied in working out depreciation under the Full Bench formula in preference to the provisions of the Seventh Schedule to the Electricity Supply Act.
